Bill Schmeisser and Joe Zoller,
Hopkins delegates to the convention of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse League held in
New York last Saturday came
home with a very favorable report
of the convention. The trip of the
Oxford lacrosse team, which was
the principal work of the meeting,
was practically assured and Hopkins is almost certain of getting
a game. Mt. Washington also tried
for a game and if: they are successful in landing it, Baltimore
will have two opportunities to see
the foreigners play. The Oxford
team was urged to come over on
the first of April in order to fill
the schedule as arranged by the
colleges making up the guarantee.
The reports of coaches from all
over the country shoved that lacrosse is increasing in popularity
everywhere. This is especially
true at Syracuse where lacrosse is
more popular than baseball. A
representative of A. G. Spaulding
and Co. was present and said that
due to the widespread demand for
such a book, that company is
going to print a lacrosse guide,
next spring. This man asked permission of the convention to gather information for this book.
Mr. Whiting, a lacrosse star on
a former international championship team, as spokesman for his
team, offered a cup for the winning college team in 1922. Such
a cup would be an added attraction for the sport and would be a
conducive influence for rivalry between the colleges. The meeting
accepted this offer with enthusiasm.
Representatives from all the
colleges in the league were present at the convention and besides
these there were delegates from
Naval Academy, Princeton, Rutgers, Montclair Athletic Club,
Crescent Athletic Club and Mt.
Washington Athletic Club.
The game between Hopkins and
Princeton will probably not take
Place on June 3rd as was proposed,
because Princeton's examinations
Will be held at that time. At the
convention it was suggested that
all teams keep this date open so
that the winning teams of the
Northern and Southern Leagues
can play for the national championship at that time. The Hopkins schedule is now filled out and
after the exams the work of perfecting a team will start in full
force.
MUSICAL CLUB CONCERT
POSTPONED

The concert, which was to be
given by the Musical Club at Western High School on Friday, January 20, has been postponed until
after the mid-year exams. This
concert was postponed because satisfactory arrangements had not
been made with the school board at
'Western and also because the time
could be used more advantageously
by the members of the club in
'cramming." No more rehearsals
will be held by the clubs until after
exams unless a special notice is
Posted on the bulletin board.

Strenuous Practice in Preparation for
Armory Games.

A most attractive schedule for
the track team during Easter week
has been .arranged by Manager
Fortney. About twenty men will
make the trip, which will cover a
period of one week, during which
time the Black and Blue "Mercuries" and "Samsons" will engage in
three meets.
On April 13 the team will journey to Lexington, where Virginia
Military Institute will be met.
Upon completion of the V. M. I.
contest Hopkins will move over to
Charlottesville to engage in a triangular - meet with Princeton and
the University of Virginia. This
meet should be interesting, not only
from the standpoint of track but
also because of the relations between Hopkins and the two schools.
k victory for us would to some extent, at least, avenge our 13-7 defeat in football at the hands of the
Virginian$, and would likewise
show Princeton that she is engaging a worthy opponent in placing
J. H. U. on her athletic schedules.
There should be some keen competition especially between the famous
Lourie, of Princeton, and our own
Clarke in the hundred.
April 18 will again see the Black
and Blue in Lexington, this time
ful the purpose of crushing Washington and Lee, a college with
which Hopkins is resuming very
close athletic relations.
Today completes the second week
of intensive training at the Armory, in preparation for the mammoth indoor meet. For the purpose
of having the team properly prepared, Manager Fortney is at present dickering for indoor meets in
New York on the two Saturdays
vreceding the games at the Fifth
Regiment Armory.
An announcement of extreme importance and one which should be
carefully noticed, has been made
by the management to the effect
that every Tuesday is considered
tryout day. Dashes, relay races,
etc., will be engaged in and upon
the results of these will depend to
a large extent the personnel of this
year's track team.
CITY CONSIDERING VARIOUS SITES
FOR NEW STADIUM

The city is having its own troubles selecting a site for its proposed stadium which seems as far
frlim realization as ever. Hopkins
can be congratulated that it decided to pursue its own course with
regard to this matter, for, since its
inception, the city idea has been
subjected to bitter sectional disputes and all sorts of delays.
Several improvement associations have commended the erection
of a stadium at Mount Royal, but
the one most concerned, the Mt.
Royal Improvement Association, is
unalterably opposed to it. The
Pennsylvania Railroad has plans
for the enlargement of its nearby
tunnel, which would considerably
interfere with any bowl on this site.
Lake Clifton, suggested by the
Engineers' Club, appears highly inadequate from the standpoint of location, undesirability of its approaches and lack of nearby parking space.

for First Meet of Season. Should
Return Victorious.

The swimming team will engage
in its first meet of the year, tomorrow, when it meets the Swarthmore aggregation in the Swarthmore tank.
Manager Davidge
Rowland will take a full squad on
the trip in an effort to repeat last
year's performance, when the Garnet was swamped by the Black and
Blue to the tune of 42-18.
The team has been practicing
consistently ig.r the last week and
the finishing touches were put on
yesterday afternoon at the B. A. C.
pool. Although it has not been
definitely decided, it is probable
that the following men will swim:
50-yard Dash—Johnston, Rowland.
100-yard Dash—Norvell, Rowland.
220-yard Swim—Coady.
Plunge—Hambleton.
Dive—Coady.
Back Stroke--Hambleton.
Relay—Coady, Rowland, Morrell, Slingluf.

Dunning, Summers and Howard
are among the new men who are
showing up well and it is possible
that one of these may be taken
along at the last moment.
The team has been handicapped
by the loss of several of its stars
who are on the blacklist. The difficult part of the schedule will not
occur until per the mid-year, however, when it is hoped that these
men will be eligible to compete.
The remainder of the schedule follows:
February 4—Syracuse, at Syracuse.
February 11—Lehigh University, at the B. A. C.
• February 18 (Afternoon)—Rutgers, at New Brunswick.
February 18 (Evening)—ColumEa, at New York.
March 4—Eastern Intercollegiate
Swimming Association.
Manager Rowland and other
members of the team are doing all
in their power to make the Lehigh
nieet a success.
As has been announced, an informal dance will follow in the B.
A. C. gymnasium and tickets are
being sold at $1.50 per couple, and
$1.00 a person. They can be procured from members of the team
or at the Andy-Landy Co. shop. It
is urged that these tickets be purchased as soon as possible, as the
success of the entire season depends
upon the outcome of this meet.
SIGMA CHI BETA PLANS DANCE

A meeting of Sigma Chi Beta
was held at the Beta Theta Pi
house last Friday night. Plans for
a dance to be given in February
were discussed. It was suggested
that men from the graduating
classes of the prep schools in the
city be invited. By this plan Sigma
Chi Beta hopes to influence some of
them to come to Hopkins.
Another meeting was held Tuesday in the M. E. Building, at which
further arrangements for the dance
were made. A final vote was taken
on the new men, and those elected
will be pledged during the next few
days.
